Situation1: A family member has a significant event they want to share with everyone.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: Thunderstorm cells force multiple flights to reroute, increasing handoffs between sectors.
Story: I sat at my desk, headset pressed to my ear, eyes darting between radar screens as thunderstorm cells lit up the map in angry red. Flights were stacking up, pilots requesting new headings, and my team needed every ounce of focus I could muster. My phone buzzed on the desk—my daughter’s name flashed on the screen. I knew what it was about: tonight was the night my grandson would reveal the results of his college entrance exams, a moment the whole family had been waiting for. They expected me to be there, to share in the joy or comfort the disappointment, to be the steady presence I’d always promised. But the storm outside was chaos, and my colleagues depended on me to keep the skies safe. My heart twisted as I stared at the phone, torn between the voices in my ear and the voices waiting for me at home, each demanding a part of me I couldn’t give all at once.
